Award.AwardTitle: Novel PT(II) Reagents for RNA Biochemistry
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Victoria DeRose from the University of Oregon to develop new metal-based compounds for predicting the structure of ribonucleic acid (RNA) biopolymers. A major realization in the post-genomic era is the extent to which cellular RNA governs gene expression through different mechanisms, many of which are still being discovered. The prediction and determination of the structure of large RNAs are significant challenges in the pursuit of the elucidation of these mechanisms. Small chemical probes can be powerful tools for the identifying structural elements of RNA. The platinum-based compounds and methods developed in this project are designed to provide such new tools for high-throughput RNA structure prediction. As this project requires use of a combination of synthesis, molecular biology, and analytical and computational methods, it fosters interdisciplinary interactions between different branches of chemistry, and it provides a workforce training environment for undergraduate and graduate students, including women, who prepare for careers in STEM fields.

The specific goals of this program are to develop square-planar, exchange-inert Pt(II) complexes as RNA crosslinking reagents and use them as tools for RNA structure characterization. Pt(II) compounds crosslink purine-rich but noncanonical regions of RNA, such as internal loops and junctions. Pt(II)-crosslinked species are robust through RNA isolation methods but reversible in mild conditions. To enable crosslink analysis, azide- or alkyne-modified Pt(II)-"Click" reagents with installed handles for selective post-treatment modification of Pt(II)-RNA species will be synthesized. Structure analysis protocols will be developed based on the unique chemistry of the Pt(II) complexes, including high-throughput sequencing methods and high-resolution mass spectrometry. Phosphorothioate "bait" ligands will be incorporated in RNA to create new crosslinking sites for the metal complexes. Efforts to enhance the properties of Pt(II) reagents for RNA structure analysis will include modification of clickable mononuclear compounds with longer linkers and testing of multinuclear Pt(II) compounds. The Pt(II)-based crosslinking methods described here have the potential to become tools for RNA structure prediction and in-cell probes of RNA accessibility to small molecules.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of this project are to understand the interactions of small metal complexes with nucleic acids and other biomolecules in cells, and to use these interactions to gain information about biomolecule structure and function.  One of the most exciting targets is cellular RNA, which has important roles in regulating cell processes and also takes on a large number of different structures that affect activity. Despite knowing the sequence of RNA, it is difficult to predict RNA structure in cells, or how it may interact with proteins and perform specific functions. In this work, we created new metal-based compounds that enter cells and bind to RNA, as well as proteins and DNA. These new compounds are based on Pt(II), which forms long-lived crosslinks that can be isolated and identified. The Pt compounds were modified with a reactive ‘click handle’ that can be used to isolate the Pt-bound biomolecules. This project period developed several new Pt compounds, deployed them in cells, and detected their localization and bound targets using imaging and high-throughput methods. It was found that these compounds localize to the nucleolus and to the endoplasmic reticulum of cells, both of which are regions dense in nucleic acids (ribosomes) as well as other biomolecules. To predict the sites where Pt might bind on ribosomes, a high-throughput bioinformatics approach was developed and major sites predicted to occur near the peptide exit tunnel of this RNA-protein machine. These results provide new information about the accessibility of different cell components to metal ion complexes, and new tools to explore these questions. This work was disseminated in published papers, student PhD and Honors undergraduate theses, and several seminars at other Universities and national and international meetings. 

A very important outcome of this project is the training of students in an interdisciplinary environment that includes chemical synthesis, biomolecular structure, and bioanalytical methods. Over this project period, nine graduate and six undergraduate students participated in aspects of the work. Five graduate students, including two women and one international visitor, developed chemical synthetic skills creating novel platinum compounds and were involved in their cellular analysis. Four graduate students developed skills in analyzing the targets of these compounds in cells, including using high-throughput bioinformatics approaches. Four students obtained PhDs during this period; two are now employed in biotechnology companies, one is an Assistant Professor where they will continue to train undergraduates in research, and one is a postdoctoral researcher. Of the six undergraduate students, two are now in excellent PhD programs, two are employed in biotechnology, and two are still finishing their undergraduate degrees. Of the 15 students trained during this period, 9 are women and 6 are underrepresented minorities and/or first-generation students. Because of the broad training in this project, students are equipped with a variety of skills that enable them to enter the workforce from different perspectives.

Group members working on this project are also committed to outreach that develops the next generation of scientists and improves science communication out to the public. Students on this project participated in a Science Literacy Program that develops methods for teaching science to non-science majors. They also participated in an Alan Alda Science Communication Workshop designed to enhance their abilities to communicate their work to the public. Finally, two PhD students were embedded in the local elementary schools through the UO STEM-Core program, where they developed projects to excite young students in science.
